Title: How to prove $\text{Rank}(AB)\leq \min(\text{Rank}(A), \text{Rank}(B))$?
AcceptedAnswer:
I used a way to prove this, which I thought may not be the most concise way but it feels very intuitive to me.
The matrix $AB$ is actually a matrix that consist the linear combination of $A$ with $B$ the multipliers. So it looks like...
$$\boldsymbol{AB}=\begin{bmatrix}
 &  &  & \\ 
a_1 & a_2 & ... & a_n\\ 
 &  &  & 
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
 &  &  & \\ 
b_1 & b_2 & ... & b_n\\ 
 &  &  & 
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
 &  &  & \\ 
\boldsymbol{A}b_1 & \boldsymbol{A}b_2 & ... & \boldsymbol{A}b_n\\ 
 &  &  & 
\end{bmatrix}$$
Suppose if $B$ is singular, then when $B$, being the multipliers of $A$, will naturally obtain another singular matrix of $AB$. Similarly, if $B$ is non-singular, then $AB$ will be non-singular. Therefore, the $rank(AB) \leq rank(B)$. Then now if $A$ is singular, then clearly, no matter what $B$ is, the $rank(AB)\leq rank(A)$. The $rank(AB)$ is immediately capped by the rank of $A$ unless the the rank of $B$ is even smaller. Put these two ideas together, the rank of $AB$ must have been capped the rank of $A$ or $B$, which ever is smaller. Therefore, $rank(AB) \leq min(rank(A), rank(B))$. Hope this helps you!
